column1: Coronado is a resort city located in San Diego County
column2: California
column3: USA
column4: across the San Diego Bay from downtown San Diego. It was founded in the 1880s and incorporated in 1890. Its population was 24

column1: Coronado is a tied island connected to the mainland by a thin strip of land called the Silver Strand. The explorer Sebastian Vizcaino gave Coronado its name and drew its first map in 1602.

column2: and thus it is nicknamed The Crown City. Its name is derived from the four off-shore islands, Los Guatro Martires Coronados (Spanish for The Four Crowned Martyrs"). Three ships of the United States Navy have been named after the city
column3: including USS Coronado.

column1: Coronado was incorporated as a town on December 11
column2: 1890. The community's first post office predates Coronado's incorporation
column3: established on February 8
column5: with Norbert Moser assigned as the first postmaster. The land was purchased by Elisha Spurr Babcock
column7: and Jacob Gruendike. Their intention was to create a resort community
column9: the Coronado Beach Company was organized. By 1888
column10: they had built the Hotel del Coronado and the city became a major resort destination. They also built a schoolhouse

column2: a tourist/vacation area just south of the Hotel del Coronado was established by John D. Spreckels and named Tent City. Spreckels also became the Hotel's Owner. Over the years the tents gave way to cottages
column3: the last of which was torn down in late 1940 or early 1941.

column2: Coronado had streetcars running on Orange Avenue. These streetcars became a fixture of the city until their retirement in 1939.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 32.7 square miles (85 km2);  20.5 km2 (7.9 mi2) of the city is land and 24.7 square miles (64 km2) of it (75.72%) is water.
Coronado is a peninsula and is connected to the mainland by a strip of land called the Silver Strand.  The Silver Strand
column3: Coronado and North Island
column4: form San Diego Bay.  Since recorded history
column5: Coronado was mostly separated from North Island by a shallow inlet of water called the Spanish Bight.  The development of North Island by the United States Navy prior to and during World War II led to the filling of the bight by July 1944
column6: combining the land areas into a single body. The Navy still operates Naval Air Station North Island (NASNI or "North Island") on Coronado. On the southern side of the town is Naval Amphibious Base Coronado
column7: a training center for Navy SEALs and Special warfare combatant-craft crewmen (SWCC). Both facilities are part of the larger Naval Base Coronado complex.  Coronado has increased in size due to dredge material being dumped on its shoreline and through the natural accumulation of sand.  The "Country Club" area on the northwest side of Coronado
column8: the "Glorietta" area and golf course on the southeast side of Coronado

column10: most of the Strand Naval Housing
column11: and most of the Coronado Cays (all on the south side of Coronado) were built on dirt dredged from San Diego Bay.

column3: the gambling ship SS Monte Carlo
column7:
was shipwrecked on the beach about a quarter mile south of the Hotel del Coronado.In 1969, the San Diego–Coronado Bridge was opened, allowing much faster transit between the cities than bay ferries or driving via State Route 75 along the Silver Strand. The bridge is made up of five lanes, one of which is controlled by a moveable barrier that allows for better traffic flow during rush hours. In the morning, the lane is moved to create three lanes going south-bound towards Coronado, and in the evening it is moved again to create three lanes going north-bound towards downtown San Diego.


=== Climate ===
According to the Köppen climate classification system, Coronado has a semi-arid climate, abbreviated BSk" on climate maps.

column1: Coronado is governed by a city council
column2: which is presided over by a directly-elected mayor.  The mayor and councilmembers serve 4-year terms.  Council designates one of its members as Mayor Pro Tempore.Coronado has long been a Republican stronghold; in 2013
column3: about 47% of voters were registered Republican
column5: and 24% nonpartisan.The resort city has voted for the Republican nominee in each presidential election since at least 1964. From 1968–1988
column6: all six Republican presidential candidates received over 70% of the vote each. However the city has been trending Democratic in recent years
column7: with each of the last three Republican candidates receiving less than 60% of the vote. In 2016
column8: Donald Trump won Coronado with a plurality of the vote
column9: and Hillary Clinton received the largest share of the vote for a Democratic candidate since at least 1964.In the California State Legislature
column10: Coronado is in the  39th Senate District
column13: represented by Democrat Todd Gloria. In the United States House of Representatives
column14: Coronado is located in California's 52nd congressional district
column15: which has a Cook partisan voting index of D+2 and is represented by Democrat Scott Peters.

column1: Tourism is an essential component of Coronado's economy.  This city is home to three major resorts (Hotel del Coronado
column2: Coronado Island Marriott and Loews Coronado Bay Resort) as well as several other hotels and inns. The downtown district along Orange Avenue with its many shops
column3: restaurants and theaters is also a key part of the local economy. Many of the restaurants are highly rated and provide a wide variety of cuisine choices.In 2008
column4: the Travel Channel rated Coronado Beach as the sixth best beach in America.

column1: Coronado is home to the famous Hotel del Coronado
column2: built in 1888 and long considered one of the world's top resorts. It is listed as a National Historic Landmark and has hosted many notable guests
column3: including the American presidents George H. W. Bush

column1: Famous actresses Mary Pickford and Marilyn Monroe also stayed there.
The Del has appeared in numerous works of popular culture and was supposedly the inspiration for the Emerald City in The Wonderful Wizard of Oz. It is rumoured that the city's main street
column2: Orange Avenue
column3: was Baum's inspiration for the yellow brick road. However
column4: other sources say Oz was inspired by the "White City" of the Chicago World's Fair of 1893. Author L. Frank Baum would have been able to see the hotel from his front porch overlooking Star Park. Baum designed the crown chandeliers in the hotel's dining room. Because of the reported association with Oz
column5: Coronado is often associated with the color green and is sometimes referred to as "The Emerald City". The colors of Coronado High are green and white; the Coronado city flag is a tricolor of green-white-green with a crown in the middle; and a local surf/skate shop is named Emerald City. The hotel is said to be haunted
column6: with room 3372 being visited by the ghost of Kate Morgan.

column2: the Hotel Del is now owned by the Blackstone Group (60%)
column3: Strategic Hotels & Resorts Inc. (34.5%)
column4: and KSL Resorts (5.5%). When Strategic Hotels & Resorts Inc. bought its stake in 2006
column5: the hotel was valued at $745 million; currently
column6: the hotel is valued at roughly $590 million.
